sample.value:
Data from 40 participants will be collected based on an a
priori power analysis with a desired power of .80 (α = .05, two-tailed) to detect a Cohen’s d of 0.45 for the difference between hit rate in the no-offloading and offloading conditions. This is a conservative approximation of half the effect size usually found in the proportion of freely recalled items between no-offloading and offloading.

analyses.value:
Hit rate, False alarm rate, Sensitivity, and Correct response time will each be analyzed in the same manner. That is, a paired-samples t-test will compare the means between no-offloading and offloading conditions.

Parallel set of analyses will be conducted using mixed effects logistic regression for hit rate and false alarm rate.

outliers.value: Participants will be replaced if their data shows that they were unable to follow procedures or task instructions (e.g., they did not write down the right words during encoding/study), or if performance was at or below chance.

dependent.value: Key dependent variables are hit rate, as indexed by proportion of items correctly rated as "old" (hits) and sensitivity (d').

conditions.value: Offloading and no-offloading will be a within-participant factor.

hypothesis.value: Previous work has consistently found a cost of offloading (when unexpectedly without the external store) in free recall performance. We extend this to recognition memory. Specifically, we investigate whether recognition memory for offloaded information differs from recognition memory for memorized information.

question2a.value:
Social support: between-participants IV with 3 levels
o	Holding the hand of a supportive individual (romantic partner) during the task
o	Activating the mental representation of this supportive individual (romantic partner) with a photograph before the task
o	Control group: being alone during the task

question2b.value: Pain ratings after a cold pressor task (immerse one hand in a container full of ice water). Score obtained on a scale of pain rating.

question3b.value:
Social support felt (check-variable).
How long participants have been in a romantic relationship.
How participants evaluate the quality of their romantic relationship.
When was the last time participants had an argument with their partner.

question10b.value:
Material:
o	2 rooms (one for the task, one to fill in the questionnaires quietly)
o	A consent form
o	Pens
o	A table
o	A container with ice water, on the table
o	2 chairs next to the container
o	Towels
o	A camera that records image and sound
o	Questionnaires

Procedure:
Participants in first semester of their Psychological Bachelor, following a methodological class, speaking fluently French or English, and having a romantic partner who’s not above the first year of a Psychological Bachelor will be accepted. Participants will be randomized in two experimental groups; to do so, a simple randomization with Excel will be done on the participants list. Participants will not be informed of the existence of the 2 groups. Each participant, regardless of their experimental group, will be scheduled for a 30-minute experiment. One group – hand-holding condition – will be asked to schedule this experiment with their romantic partner and to come to the experiment with this person. The second group – photograph condition – will be asked to schedule this experiment for themselves only and to take a photograph of their romantic partner with them. During the experiment, the procedure will be quite the same in both conditions:
o	First, participants will be informed of the experimental procedure (immerse one of their hands in a container full of ice water during 2 minutes while holding their partner’s hand / after having looked at their partner’ photograph; rate their pain using a questionnaire; answering to a questionnaire about their romantic relationship; answering to some demographic questions). They will also be informed that the task (2 minutes with hand in the container) will be filmed.
o	Second, participants will be given the chance to leave if they don’t want to continue the experiment. Those who stay will be asked to sign a consent form. For couples, both partners will be asked to sign this consent form. Those consent forms will be numbered, and the number on each consent form will be reported on the questionnaires of the same participants.
o	Third, participants will be placed next to the container full of ice water. Hand-holding group will be asked to hold their partner’s hand (the partner will seat right next to them), whereas photograph group will be asked to look at their partner’ photograph for one minute.
o	Fourth, after explaining to the couple that they are not allowed to speak to each other during the task, the experimenter will leave the room. All participants will be asked to put one of their hand in the container (the hand not holding the partner for the hand-holding group) when hearing a “bip”. A timer will begin as soon as the hand is in the container and will ring after 2 minutes.
o	Fifth, after hearing the second “bip”, participants will be asked to take their hand out of the container and to let go of their partner’s hand for the hand-holding group. Towels will be given in order to dry their hand. The experimenter will come back in the room.
o	Sixth, participants will be placed alone in a quiet room to fill in the pain questionnaire, the questionnaire about their romantic relationship, and the demographic questions. All participants will be alone to fill in those questionnaires in order to avoid an influence of: the person conducting the study (time pressure); the romantic partner (pressure on the information given about their relationship).
o	Finally, participants will receive their credit for their participation, will be thanked and will leave.

question4b.value: Participant shouldn’t be aware of the theoretical background of the study in order to prevent their knowledge from interfere with their behavior; therefore, participants shouldn’t be in second year of a Bachelor in Psychology or above. Moreover, only participants speaking fluently French or English will be accepted. Then, only participant having a romantic partner for more than 1 month will be recruited. This loving partner shouldn’t be in second year of a Bachelor in Psychology or above. Participants will also be told that they must be in good physical health in order to participate; no illnesses in relation with pain or with the heart.

question5b.value: Data will be collected in the University of Lausanne. Participants will be recruited in a first-year methodological psychological course in exchange of credits. The recruiting and the experiment per-se will take place during the first semester in order to have a sample as naïve as possible regarding the theoretical background of the study. Therefore, at the beginning of the year, a PhD student is going to briefly present the subject of the study (without talking about the expected outcomes) in the methodological class. Then, students will be able to register to the study during one week. Once it will be done, the experiment will begin.

question7b.value: As participants will all be recruited before beginning the study, an additional 30 participants will be added to the planned sample size; this is because some students could unsubscribe between the time they sign up and the time the experiment begin. Thus, when a total of 300 registrations is reached, the study will begin.

question8b.value:
a) Participants registered but who will not show up to the study, or participants who will leave during the experiment (without having finished it) will be excluded.
b) Participants reporting no social support felt will be excluded.
c) As participants will be recruited only if they speak fluently French or English, no other demographic exclusions will be done after data collection.
d) Data-based outliers will be excluded after analyses; if the multiple analyses reveal serious outliers and if those outliers have a real impact on the results, they will be excluded.
e) In the hand-holding condition, if participants spoke with their partner during the task, their reports will be analyzed carefully.

question1a.value:
1)	Holding one’s romantic partner’s hand will reduce physical-pain experience compared to the physical-pain experienced without the romantic partner being around or without the mental activation of his/her presence.
2)	Activating the mental representation of a supportive other (romantic partner) will reduce physical-pain experience compared to the physical-pain experienced without the romantic partner being around or without the mental activation of his/her presence.
3)	Activating the mental representation of one’s partner will reduce physical-pain experience as much as holding one’s partner’s hand, compared to the physical-pain experienced without the romantic partner being around or without the mental activation of his/her presence.

question3a.value: In this study, it is important that participants feel social support in order to see if this social support felt has an influence on the physical pain felt. Thus, a check will be done to see whether participants are feeling social support or not. This check-variable will be assessed as a score on a social support scale. The manipulation will not be successful if participants report no social support felt.

question5a.value: Social support is associated with reduced pain experience across several domains (Cogan & Spinnato, 1988; Kulik & Mahler, 1989; Zaza & Baine, 2002), and this connection may reflect a causal relationship (Brown, Sheffield, Leary, & Robinson, 2003; Jackson, Iezzi, Chen, Ebnet, & Eglitis, 2005). Moreover, the mere presence of another supportive individual (vs. being alone) reduced pain ratings (McClelland & McCubbin, 2008; Montoya, Larbig, Braun, Preissl, & Birbaumer, 2004). Aside from that, previous work has shown that activating mental representations of important others can produce effects similar to those created by the actual presence of these individuals (Fitzsimons & Bargh, 2003; Mikulincer & Shaver, 2001).

question6a.value: Hypothesis 1) would be predicted by social support, causal and mere presence previous findings, whereas hypothesis 2) would be predicted by mental representations previous findings.

question1c.value:
Physical pain rating: pain scale with several items; an aggregate pain-rate score will be calculated.
Social support report: social support scale with several items; an aggregate social support felt score will be calculated.
The length of participants relationship, in months.
The reported quality of participants relationship: scale with several items; an aggregate quality score will be calculated.
When was the last time participants had an argument with their partner, in days and hours (if relevant).

question2c.value: As we want to see the differences between 3 different groups (hand-holding, photograph, control) on a DV (pain rating), an ANOVA will be conducted. As groups are independent, we will conduct a one-way ANOVA. As we have 3 different groups, contrasts analyses will also be conducted.

question3c.value:
IV = social support (hand-holding condition; photograph condition; control condition)
DV = physical pain rating
Check-variable = social support report
Control variables = relationship length; relationship quality; last argument.

question4c.value:
Social support report: this is the chek-variable of the study; if no social support is felt by participants, no impact will be seen on the pain-rating.
The length of participants relationship: as longer relationships are supposed to have built more confidence in each other, participants who’ve been in a relationship longer may report more social support felt.
The reported quality of participants relationship: if a participant feels they are in a quality relationship, they will possibly report more social support felt.
When was the last time participants had an argument with their partner: if participants had an argument with their partner right before the experiment, they may report less social support felt.

attributes.title: I’m About to Lose Control (And I’m Not sure I Like It): The Role of Sense of Agency in the Acceptance of Automated Decisions - PART2

q1.value: I’m About to Lose Control (And I’m Not sure I Like It): The Role of Sense of Agency in the Acceptance of Automated Decisions - PART 2

q2.value: Gabi Schaap, Tibor Bosse, Paul Hendriks Vettehen, Yana van de Sande, Hanna Schraffenberger

q3.value:
Digital technology is already making decisions in finance, health, dating, commerce, and many other domains that affect our everyday lives, whether we like it or not. Until recently, much of this decision-making was strictly a privilege of humans. As machines are increasingly acting as autonomous agents, fears are that ultimately we will give up the idea that humans are autonomous agents. The main questions are: 
1.	As we encounter machine-made decisions, do we feel that our sense of being autonomous agents is compromised? 
2.	What are the circumstances under which we accept the technology and its decisions regardless?
The study will do this by measuring the effects of machine vs human decisions on Sense of Agency and acceptance of decision and technology. We will examine whether the level of control over a decision exerted by the user as well as the added value of the decision affect this relation.

q4.value:
Research Questions
RQ1: To what extent do machine decisions result in different (higher or lower) SoA than human decisions?

RQ2: To what extent does the nature of the agent (human or machine) interact with the level of user control in predicting SoA?

Hypotheses
H1: A higher level of user control over decisions results in a greater SoA
H2: A greater SoA leads to greater acceptance of both decision and agent
H3: A greater added value of the decision diminishes the effect of SoA on decision and agent acceptance

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

q7.value: The study is an online experiment, so there will be no actual interaction between subjects and experimenters.

question.value: 2(Agent: Machine/Human) x2(Control: user control/no control) x2 (added value: high/low) between-subjects experiment. The experiment will be administered online.

q9.value: We will use simple randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the eight conditions. We will use the randomization function in the Qualtrics software application (https://www.qualtrics.com) to assign participants to each condition.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will use the Prolific Academic survey platform to recruit participants (https://www.prolific.co). We will include adult (>18 y.o.) participants from the UK only, starting February 2020 until full sample size (completed questionnaires) is obtained. Participants will be paid €1,42 for max. 10 minutes of participation (only fully completed questionnaires).

q13.value: Our target sample size is 400 participants (fully completed questionnaires)

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .95 power to detect a medium effect size of .25 at the standard .05 alpha error probability. The experiment includes 8 treatment groups, with main effects and interactions.

question.value:
In each condition participants read the same scenario in which a decision is made regarding their own financial investment in the stock market. 

Agent (levels: machine or human): The ‘Agent’ factor presents the decision as made by either a machine or a human expert, both of whom base their decision on the same extensive data. The scenario will state whether the agent making the decision is an ‘expert’ or an 'algorithm'.

Control (levels: high/low) The ‘Control’ factor presents the scenario as either an automatic decision that will be executed without the participant’s control or a recommendation that awaits the participant’s approval. 

Low control: “The [algorithm/expert] will automatically choose which investments to make for you. You cannot influence the decision; the [algorithm/expert] takes it for you.

The sum will automatically be transferred from your bank account.”

High control: “The [algorithm/expert] will advise which investments to make for you. You will have control over the decision; you can choose to follow the advice or not.

You may or may not give permission to transfer the sum from your bank account. It is up to you.”


Added value (levels: high/low) will be manipulated by adding either a high or low estimation of return on investment rate to each scenario: 

Low added value: "Based on prior experience with this algorithm, it is estimated that the current decision will result in a profit of 2% on your investment."

High added value: "Based on prior experience with this algorithm, it is estimated that the current decision will result in a profit of 20% on your investment."

After reading the scenario (see below), participants fill out a questionnaire, containing the following variables:

Q1 Sense of Agency: 
“We want to know how you feel about the decision making in this scenario. If this would really happen to me, in this scenario, I would feel that…”
[1=strongly disagree, 7= strongly agree]

1.	I had full control over the decision
2.	The decision was up to me, and no one else
3.	I was able to make my own decision


Q2 Acceptance of decision: 
“We want to know how you feel about the decision that was made regarding the investment of your money in the stock market.“

1.	I accept this decision [1=not at all, 7=completely]
2.	I agree with the decision [1=not at all, 7=completely]


Q3 Acceptance of decision maker/technology:
“The decision to invest your money was made by an [algorithm/expert]. We want to know how you feel about the [algorithm/expert]”. Assuming that in real life, you would be willing and able to invest money in stocks, how would you feel about using the [algorithm/expert]?”

1.	Assuming I had access to the system/expert, I intend to use [it/him or her]. 
2.	Given that I had access to the system/expert, I predict that I would use [it/him or her] [1=strongly disagree, 7= strongly agree]
We will use Hayes’(2017) PROCESS model 21 for the analyses, to test direct, indirect and conditional effects

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining significance.

q22.value:
-Data will be checked for response sets. Participants exhibiting response set will be excluded from the analyses
-Participants failing an instructed response test will be excluded from the analyses
-In the hypotheses tests, outliers with a standardized score higher than 3, will be excluded.
-Also, anyone who completed the questionnaire in under 2 mins. will be excluded.

q23.value: We will only include complete questionnaires in our sample and analyses

q24.value: Other exploratory analyses may include general attitudes regarding the decision and agent

q25.value: Hayes, A. F. (2017). Introduction to mediation, moderation, and conditional process analysis: A regression-based approach. Guilford Publications.

-Participants failing an instructed response test will be excluded from the analyses
-In the hypotheses tests, outliers with a standardized score higher than 3, will be excluded.
-Also, anyone who completed the questionnaire in under 2 mins. will be excluded.

registration_responses.q8.question: 2(Agent: Machine/Human) x2(Control: user control/no control) x2 (added value: high/low) between-subjects experiment. The experiment will be administered online.
registration_responses.q12.question: We will use the Prolific Academic survey platform to recruit participants (https://www.prolific.co). We will include adult (>18 y.o.) participants from the UK only, starting February 2020 until full sample size (completed questionnaires) is obtained. Participants will be paid €1,42 for max. 10 minutes of participation (only fully completed questionnaires).
registration_responses.q16.question:
In each condition participants read the same scenario in which a decision is made regarding their own financial investment in the stock market. 

Agent (levels: machine or human): The ‘Agent’ factor presents the decision as made by either a machine or a human expert, both of whom base their decision on the same extensive data. The scenario will state whether the agent making the decision is an ‘expert’ or an 'algorithm'.

Control (levels: high/low) The ‘Control’ factor presents the scenario as either an automatic decision that will be executed without the participant’s control or a recommendation that awaits the participant’s approval. 

Low control: “The [algorithm/expert] will automatically choose which investments to make for you. You cannot influence the decision; the [algorithm/expert] takes it for you.

The sum will automatically be transferred from your bank account.”

High control: “The [algorithm/expert] will advise which investments to make for you. You will have control over the decision; you can choose to follow the advice or not.

You may or may not give permission to transfer the sum from your bank account. It is up to you.”


Added value (levels: high/low) will be manipulated by adding either a high or low estimation of return on investment rate to each scenario: 

Low added value: "Based on prior experience with this algorithm, it is estimated that the current decision will result in a profit of 2% on your investment."

High added value: "Based on prior experience with this algorithm, it is estimated that the current decision will result in a profit of 20% on your investment."
registration_responses.q17.question:
After reading the scenario (see below), participants fill out a questionnaire, containing the following variables:

Q1 Sense of Agency: 
“We want to know how you feel about the decision making in this scenario. If this would really happen to me, in this scenario, I would feel that…”
[1=strongly disagree, 7= strongly agree]

1.	I had full control over the decision
2.	The decision was up to me, and no one else
3.	I was able to make my own decision


Q2 Acceptance of decision: 
“We want to know how you feel about the decision that was made regarding the investment of your money in the stock market.“

1.	I accept this decision [1=not at all, 7=completely]
2.	I agree with the decision [1=not at all, 7=completely]


Q3 Acceptance of decision maker/technology:
“The decision to invest your money was made by an [algorithm/expert]. We want to know how you feel about the [algorithm/expert]”. Assuming that in real life, you would be willing and able to invest money in stocks, how would you feel about using the [algorithm/expert]?”

1.	Assuming I had access to the system/expert, I intend to use [it/him or her]. 
2.	Given that I had access to the system/expert, I predict that I would use [it/him or her] [1=strongly disagree, 7= strongly agree]
registration_responses.q19.question: We will use Hayes’(2017) PROCESS model 21 for the analyses, to test direct, indirect and conditional effects

question2a.value:
VI : support social, avec 3 modalités: 
1. Support social réel (présence de la ou du partenaire romantique tenant la main)
2. Support social activé par représentation mentale (photo de la ou du partenaire)
3. Groupe contrôle: absence de support social (participant·e accompli la tâche seul·e)

Variable et plan expérimental inter-sujets. Les sujets seront attribués aléatoirement entre conditions expérimentales.

question2b.value: VD: douleur reportée sur une échelle unidimensionnelle d'intensité de la douleur (en 10 point – de absence totale de douleur à douleur maximale) lors d'un test au froid de 2 minutes (immersion de la main dans un bac d'eau glacée).

question3b.value: Support social perçu (variable pour le "manipulation check").

question10b.value:
Le recrutement sera fait auprès des étudiant·e·s suivant le cours de méthodologie, en 1ère année du Bachelor de psychologie. Seules les personnes n'ayant aucune problématique de santé, physique ou psychique, et ayant une ou un partenaire romantique seront acceptées. Les participant·e·s seront distribués de manière complétement aléatoire entre les trois conditions expérimentales (randomisation effectuée sur la liste des participant·e·s) et n'auront pas connaissance du but réel de l'étude, c'est-à-dire tester le lien entre support social et expérience de la douleur. L'étude sera conduite dans les salles du laboratoire de l'Université de Lausanne.
Les participant·e·s dans la condition de support social réel (présence de la ou du partenaire romantique) devront se présenter avec leur partenaire le jour de l'expérience. Les participant·e·s dans la condition d'activation du support social par représentation mentale (photo de la ou du partenaire) devront se présenter le jour de l'expérience avec une photo de leur partenaire. Les participant·e·s du groupe contrôle, sans support social, se présenteront seul·e. 
À leur arrivée, les participants seront accueilli·e·s par la personne en charge de l'expérience qui leur expliquera la procédure expérimentale: le déroulement de l'étude et la tâche au froid. En ce qui concerne la procédure de l'expérience, elle sera similaire pour toutes les trois conditions. Les participant·e·s seront placé·e·s dans une salle, visible depuis une deuxième salle, celle où la personne en charge de l'expérience pourra observer l’entièreté de l'étude et le respect des consigne, ainsi que communiquer directement avec les participant·e·s. 
Après signature du formulaire (participant·e·s et partenaires) de consentement (participation volontaire, anonymisation des données et liberté d'interrompre l'étude sans justification), les participant·e·s devront remplir un bref formulaire avec quelques données socio-démographiques. 
Les participant·e·s seront assis·e·s à côté du récipient contentent de l'eau glacée pour la tâche au froid. Lors de la tâche au froid à proprement parler (2 minutes d'immersion de la main), la manipulation interviendra. Pour les participant·e·s dans la condition de support réel, la ou le partenaire sera invité·e à lui tenir la main; cela sans aucune interaction verbale permise. Dans la condition de support social activé par représentation mentale, la ou le participant·e sera invité·e à regarder la photo de sa ou son partenaire tout au long de la tâche. Pour le groupe sans support social, les participant·e·s exécuteront simplement la tâche au froid.
La personne en charge de l'expérience, communiquera oralement, depuis l'autre salle, le début de la tâche et la fin de celle-ci (après 2 minutes).
Une fois la tâche au froid terminée, les participant·e·s seront invité·e à sortir la main et pourront s'essuyer. L'expérimentateur reviendra à ce moment dans la salle et demandera à ou au partenaire de sortir et attendre dans la salle d'attente prévue à cet effet. Dans la condition de support social activé par représentation mentale, il enlèvera la photo de la ou du partenaire. 
Dans les trois groupes, les participant·e·s seront invité·e·s à répondre aux questions sur le support social (manipulation check) ainsi qu'à l'échelle de la douleur expérimentée durant la tâche au froid. Les participant·e·s rempliront seul·e·s ces questions et, une fois terminé, seront remercié·e·s. L'étude sera donc terminée.

question4b.value: Les participant·e·s doivent être en bonne santé physique et psychique (absence de toute pathologie liée à la douleur, son ressenti et sa perception). Les participant·e·s doivent également être en couple afin de pouvoir les attribuer aléatoirement à une des trois conditions (pour rappel, les deux conditions de support social prévoient la présence ou une photo de la ou du partenaire).

question5b.value: Etudiant·e·s universitaires (159 participant·e·s prévu·e·s), recruté·e·s vis le cours de méthodologie. Les étudiant·e·s participent de manière volontaire, signent un formulaire de consentement, mais reçoivent des points pour leur participation.

question6b.value: 159 participant·e·s: en prévision d'une ANOVA (fixed effects, omnibus, one-way) avec 3 groupes. Calcul effectué avec un effect size moyen (f = 0.25), alpha = 0.05, Power = 0.8.

question8b.value:
- Échec de la manipulation du support social (manipulation check): les participant·e·s ne reportant pas de support social perçu (dans les conditions de support social) seront exclu
- Exclusion des participant·e·s qui ne porteront pas à terme la tâche
- Interaction entre participant·e et partenaire: exclusion des participant·e·s qui interagirons verbalement avec leur partenaire durant la tâche (aucune interaction permise)
- Suspicion des sujets sur le lien testé (support social et diminution douleur) (question demandée en fin d'étude)

question1a.value: (1)	Nous nous attendons à ce que le support social, réel ou activé par représentation mentale, prédise négativement la douleur exprimée lors d'un test au froid, comparé à l'absence de support social. Plus précisément, les plus bas niveaux de douleur seront reportées chez les participant·e·s recevant du support social, soit un support social réel par la présence d'un·e partenaire romantique (1a), soit un support social activé par représentation mentale, par présentation d'une photo de la ou du partenaire (1b), en comparaison aux participant·e·s dans la condition d'absence de support social, réalisant la tâche seul·e·s. Nous ne nous attendons à aucune différence significative dans l'expérience de douleur reportée entre conditions de support social (1c).

question3a.value: Nous manipulons la variable "support social", avec trois conditions expérimentales: 1. Présence d'un autrui significatif (support social réel), 2. Photo de la ou du partenaire romantique (activation de la représentation mentale du support social), 3. Absence de support social. Afin de vérifier la manipulation, un "manipulation check" est fait concernant la perception du support social. Il sera demandé aux participant·e·s d'évaluer, sur une échelle de Likert en 7 points, la perception du support social. La manipulation sera effective en présence d'un plus fort niveau de support social perçu, lorsque celui-ci est induit (conditions 1 et 2), par rapport à la condition d'absence de support social. De la même manière, la manipulation ne sera pas effective, si les participant·e·s ne reportent aucune perception de support social.

question1c.value: Intensité de la douleur (VD): échelle unidimensionnelle d'intensité de la douleur en 10 point (0 = absence totale de douleur à 10 = douleur maximale). Le score correspond simplement à la valeur choisie sur l'échelle par la ou le participant·e.

question2c.value: ANOVA et analyse de contrastes (2 contrastes)

question3c.value:
- Intensité de la douleur : VD
- Support social : VI (à trois modalités: support réel; support activation représentation mentale; absence de support)
- Support social perçu = variable pour le "manipulation check"

attributes.title: Social tolerance and inhibitory control skills in macaque species

q1.value: Social Tolerance and Inhibitory Control Skills in Macaque Species

q2.value: Louise Loyant, Marine Joly, Jerome Micheletta, Bridget Waller

q3.value:
Living in a complex social environment requires primates to manage their emotions and inhibit impulsive behaviours to maintain group cohesion and increase their fitness. Such cognitive processes are defined as inhibitory control (Diamond, 2013; Beran, 2018). For example, a primate needs to inhibit his impulses to avoid unnecessary conflicts with group mates. Inhibitory control is thus essential during daily complex problem solving and in social interactions. 
Inhibitory control is a multi-dimensional construct comprised of separable processes: inhibition of emotions, actions and inhibition of a cognitive set (Diamond, 2013; Beran, 2018). Having a better understanding of animal inhibitory control is crucial to apprehend the evolutionary underpinnings of this ability, particularly if the selective pressures underlying can be identified. To date, we know little about the selective forces that favour the evolution of this executive function. Ecological factors and absolute brain size seem to shape inhibitory control skills (MacLean et al., 2014) but these results have provoked many controversies (Beran, 2018). As inhibitory control is crucial in the social life of primates it is particularly interesting to understand whether their social environment might affect it. It has been suggested that one route by which social problem solving can evolve is through selection on social tolerance (Hare et al., 2007). Tolerant social styles feature higher reconciliation rates, fewer conflicts and more relaxed social relationships than despotic ones (Thierry, 2000). It has been suggested that species with higher social tolerance, live in more complex groups, and need to employ more cognitive skills as inhibitory strategies ( Dunbar et al. 2007; Thierry et al. 2007).  Therefore, it would be interesting to compare inhibitory control skills in different species displaying different degrees of social tolerance. 
The macaque radiation, is an ideal taxon for such a comparative study as their social styles can be classified along a four-grade scale, from despotic style of social relations to more tolerant style ones (Thierry, 2000). 
Hence the aim of this project is to explore the influence of social tolerance degrees on each main component of inhibitory control skills: basic executive functioning, inhibition of emotions, actions and cognitive sets.

q4.value:
Our main hypothesis is that overall the more tolerant species will outperform the less tolerant ones in inhibitory control tasks. More precisely:
- We don’t expect any difference in the basic executive task between macaque species.
-  For the inhibition of emotion task, we expect that the macaques with lower degree of social tolerance will be more distracted by a negative emotional stimulus as they are more easily aroused (Thierry, 2000).
- For the inhibition of action task, our hypothesis is that macaques with a higher degree of social tolerance will have better performance at inhibiting their action. As in Joly et al., 2017, the more tolerant macaques species outperformed the less tolerant species at a basic task of inhibition of action.
- For the inhibition of a cognitive set, we expect that macaque with a higher degree of social tolerance, which has been associated with better problem-solving skills (Hare et al., 2007) will have better performance at reverse learning task.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The current study uses  a within-subject mixed design, with repeated measures. The stimuli for each task are counterbalanced with randomized position and order. The experiment is using an across subject counterbalancing avoiding order effect and sequence effect. The "Inhibition of emotions task” uses a randomized block presentation of the pictures to enhance the Stroop effect (Allritz et al., 2016) and decrease the carry over effect. We will analyse the following factors: response latency (time to realize the task, i.e. touch the target), number of taps made by the individual on the screen before touching the target, success (trials successfully performed),  abandon of the trial  (if the individual didn’t perform the task during the time limit of a trial), abandon of the session (if the individual will not continue the session after 3 attempts) and the number of facial expression from the subject toward the touch screen. We will also analyse the type of stimulus: the type of the picture for the “inhibition of emotions” task, and if  the symbol is a “Go” or a “No go” symbol for the last two tasks.

q9.value: For all the tasks the position of the target is randomized (left or right), thanks to a randomization function in Matlab. The order of the presentation of the stimuli for each task is also randomized so each individual sees the same number of stimuli and in a different order. The same stimulus is not presented more than twice in a row for the "Inhibition of action" and the "Inhibition of emotions task".

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: Data from the pilot study in one species (rhesus macaques) has already been collected, but not analysed, and it cannot be compared with other species yet.

question.value:
Macaques included in this study will be adults (more than 3 years old), male or female, housed in social groups. Some of the macaques won’t be familiar with touch screen experiments so they will have to be trained first. The testing set up will consist of a touch screen, a laptop and a camera, which will be transported from one cage to another. To ensure low stress levels, all tests will be conducted in the individuals’ normal enclosure, with no isolation from the social group. The macaques will have free and voluntary access to the apparatus and will never be restrained. At any point subjects will be able to  leave the experiment and come back when interested again. The rewards (small pieces of apple, seeds, dry raisins and peanuts) for correct answer will be given by hand. When the training phase will be  completed (i.e. after reaching a success criterion of following the target 20 trials in a row), the subjects will move to the experimental tasks. Each task consists of a defined number of trials to complete or a success criterion to reach (75% of success for the whole session for the last task of reverse learning).

Each of the task has its own procedure and criterion for completion:
-	Task 1: executive functioning
Study 1 is a Reaction Time Task, the individual has to touch a small target displayed at his left or right (a red rectangle 10x15cm) on a touch screen and will receive a reward for it. Task 1 consists of 3 sessions with 20 trials each.
-	Task 2: inhibition of emotions, “Modified Stroop Task”
We are using Reaction Time Task, measuring the time taken by the macaques to touch a target (the same target as in study 1) displayed at the same time as a picture of a conspecific’s face (neutral or threatening facial expression) or a control object on a touch screen. Task 2 consists of 3 sessions with  36 randomised trials each). 
-	Task 3: inhibition of an action, “Go noGo”
Performances of the macaques (Reaction Time and percentage of correct answers) will  be  evaluated  using a go/no go paradigm. On a touch screen, 75% of the time a target will be displayed (the “go” stimulus) and the macaques will have to touch it to receive a reward. The rest of the time a “no go” stimulus will be displayed, and the macaques will  have to suppress their impulse to touch it. Task 3 consists of 5 sessions with  20 trials each.
-	Task 4: inhibition of a cognitive set, “ Reverse Learning”
The rule learned in Study 3 will be reversed. The “go” stimulus will become a “no-go” stimulus and the “no-go” stimulus will become the “go” stimulus. For each trial, we will measure the Reaction Time and percentage  of correct answers. The criterion to complete Task 4 is 75% of success.
The subjects have 35sec to complete the trial. If the subject stays inactive for more than 5 min the session will be  stopped and continued the next testing day if available. If the subject does not  participate three testing days in a row it will definitely be excluded from the task.
The duration of the data collection phase will depend on the macaques’ performances.

question.value:
The independent variables in this study are: (1) the type of stimulus (either a rewarded stimulus, an unrewarded one, or a different type of picture for the "Modified Stroop Task"(No picture, an object, a neutral face of a conspecific, a threatening face of a conspecific)) (2) the degree of social tolerance ("low", "medium", "High" and continuous measures like conciliatory tendencies or rates of counter-aggression).
The variables identity, age, gender, group size, task experience, hierarchical rank (using ranking matrix), session, trial and block (for Task 2)  will also be taken into account.

The measured variables are the response latency (time to realize the task, i.e. touch the target), success (trials successfully performed during the whole session), number of taps made by the individual on the screen before touching the target, the number of facial expression produced while performing the task and the number of abandon.

We will calculate the mean accuracy across sessions (percentage of correct trials, i.e touching the target).  For the second task we will calculate  the difference between mean response time in trials without picture and the trials with pictures. For the third task, the Go no Go, we will calculate the accuracy of not touching the No go stimulus (% of trials when a NoGo was present and the individual didn’t touch it) and the response slowing on No go trials. Finally, for the last reverse learning task, we will calculate the difference between the number of trials to reach the criterion of success for the first rule (75% of correct trials for the whole session) minus the number of trials to reach the same criterion for the reversed rule.

To test the relationship between the independent variables (sex, age, rank, group size, task experience, type of stimulus, social tolerance, trial, session, block) and the dependent variables we will use GLMMs. Individual’s identity will be included as a random factor. Significant effects will be considered only if the model with predictors was more informative than the null model (ANOVA significant). We will also use Post Hoc comparison (Tukey HSD test, contrast method) to compare pairs of means.

q21.value: p-values of .05 will be used to establish statistical significance in the comparison of the different model using ANOVA in the GLMM and post hoc tests.

q22.value: Any reaction time inferior to 200ms will be excluded as not reflecting a meaningful action, and any reaction time superior to the time limit (35 sec) will be treated as outlier (Whelan et al., 2008; Baayen et al., 2010).

q23.value: If a macaque is too distracted to finish a session it will be continued the next testing day. If after 3 attempts the task is still not completed, the data will be analysed but the abandon before completion will be recorded.

q24.value: The variables age, gender, hierarchical rank, group size, task experience, type of stimulus, session, trial, block (for Task 2) will be controlled for.

registration_responses.q1: Social Tolerance and Inhibitory Control Skills in Macaque Species
registration_responses.q2: Louise Loyant, Marine Joly, Jerome Micheletta, Bridget Waller
registration_responses.q3:
Living in a complex social environment requires primates to manage their emotions and inhibit impulsive behaviours to maintain group cohesion and increase their fitness. Such cognitive processes are defined as inhibitory control (Diamond, 2013; Beran, 2018). For example, a primate needs to inhibit his impulses to avoid unnecessary conflicts with group mates. Inhibitory control is thus essential during daily complex problem solving and in social interactions. 
Inhibitory control is a multi-dimensional construct comprised of separable processes: inhibition of emotions, actions and inhibition of a cognitive set (Diamond, 2013; Beran, 2018). Having a better understanding of animal inhibitory control is crucial to apprehend the evolutionary underpinnings of this ability, particularly if the selective pressures underlying can be identified. To date, we know little about the selective forces that favour the evolution of this executive function. Ecological factors and absolute brain size seem to shape inhibitory control skills (MacLean et al., 2014) but these results have provoked many controversies (Beran, 2018). As inhibitory control is crucial in the social life of primates it is particularly interesting to understand whether their social environment might affect it. It has been suggested that one route by which social problem solving can evolve is through selection on social tolerance (Hare et al., 2007). Tolerant social styles feature higher reconciliation rates, fewer conflicts and more relaxed social relationships than despotic ones (Thierry, 2000). It has been suggested that species with higher social tolerance, live in more complex groups, and need to employ more cognitive skills as inhibitory strategies ( Dunbar et al. 2007; Thierry et al. 2007).  Therefore, it would be interesting to compare inhibitory control skills in different species displaying different degrees of social tolerance. 
The macaque radiation, is an ideal taxon for such a comparative study as their social styles can be classified along a four-grade scale, from despotic style of social relations to more tolerant style ones (Thierry, 2000). 
Hence the aim of this project is to explore the influence of social tolerance degrees on each main component of inhibitory control skills: basic executive functioning, inhibition of emotions, actions and cognitive sets.
registration_responses.q4:
Our main hypothesis is that overall the more tolerant species will outperform the less tolerant ones in inhibitory control tasks. More precisely:
- We don’t expect any difference in the basic executive task between macaque species.
-  For the inhibition of emotion task, we expect that the macaques with lower degree of social tolerance will be more distracted by a negative emotional stimulus as they are more easily aroused (Thierry, 2000).
- For the inhibition of action task, our hypothesis is that macaques with a higher degree of social tolerance will have better performance at inhibiting their action. As in Joly et al., 2017, the more tolerant macaques species outperformed the less tolerant species at a basic task of inhibition of action.
- For the inhibition of a cognitive set, we expect that macaque with a higher degree of social tolerance, which has been associated with better problem-solving skills (Hare et al., 2007) will have better performance at reverse learning task.

registration_responses.q8.question: The current study uses  a within-subject mixed design, with repeated measures. The stimuli for each task are counterbalanced with randomized position and order. The experiment is using an across subject counterbalancing avoiding order effect and sequence effect. The "Inhibition of emotions task” uses a randomized block presentation of the pictures to enhance the Stroop effect (Allritz et al., 2016) and decrease the carry over effect. We will analyse the following factors: response latency (time to realize the task, i.e. touch the target), number of taps made by the individual on the screen before touching the target, success (trials successfully performed),  abandon of the trial  (if the individual didn’t perform the task during the time limit of a trial), abandon of the session (if the individual will not continue the session after 3 attempts) and the number of facial expression from the subject toward the touch screen. We will also analyse the type of stimulus: the type of the picture for the “inhibition of emotions” task, and if  the symbol is a “Go” or a “No go” symbol for the last two tasks.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Macaques included in this study will be adults (more than 3 years old), male or female, housed in social groups. Some of the macaques won’t be familiar with touch screen experiments so they will have to be trained first. The testing set up will consist of a touch screen, a laptop and a camera, which will be transported from one cage to another. To ensure low stress levels, all tests will be conducted in the individuals’ normal enclosure, with no isolation from the social group. The macaques will have free and voluntary access to the apparatus and will never be restrained. At any point subjects will be able to  leave the experiment and come back when interested again. The rewards (small pieces of apple, seeds, dry raisins and peanuts) for correct answer will be given by hand. When the training phase will be  completed (i.e. after reaching a success criterion of following the target 20 trials in a row), the subjects will move to the experimental tasks. Each task consists of a defined number of trials to complete or a success criterion to reach (75% of success for the whole session for the last task of reverse learning).

Each of the task has its own procedure and criterion for completion:
-	Task 1: executive functioning
Study 1 is a Reaction Time Task, the individual has to touch a small target displayed at his left or right (a red rectangle 10x15cm) on a touch screen and will receive a reward for it. Task 1 consists of 3 sessions with 20 trials each.
-	Task 2: inhibition of emotions, “Modified Stroop Task”
We are using Reaction Time Task, measuring the time taken by the macaques to touch a target (the same target as in study 1) displayed at the same time as a picture of a conspecific’s face (neutral or threatening facial expression) or a control object on a touch screen. Task 2 consists of 3 sessions with  36 randomised trials each). 
-	Task 3: inhibition of an action, “Go noGo”
Performances of the macaques (Reaction Time and percentage of correct answers) will  be  evaluated  using a go/no go paradigm. On a touch screen, 75% of the time a target will be displayed (the “go” stimulus) and the macaques will have to touch it to receive a reward. The rest of the time a “no go” stimulus will be displayed, and the macaques will  have to suppress their impulse to touch it. Task 3 consists of 5 sessions with  20 trials each.
-	Task 4: inhibition of a cognitive set, “ Reverse Learning”
The rule learned in Study 3 will be reversed. The “go” stimulus will become a “no-go” stimulus and the “no-go” stimulus will become the “go” stimulus. For each trial, we will measure the Reaction Time and percentage  of correct answers. The criterion to complete Task 4 is 75% of success.
The subjects have 35sec to complete the trial. If the subject stays inactive for more than 5 min the session will be  stopped and continued the next testing day if available. If the subject does not  participate three testing days in a row it will definitely be excluded from the task.
The duration of the data collection phase will depend on the macaques’ performances.

q3.value:
The confirmation bias has been found in decision making, perhaps most notably in the political choice arena.  In principal, a desire to shield oneself from arguments or information that is dissonant with our beliefs can be assumed to influence information search in many domains. 
 We aim to test existence of the confirmation bias in a novel food information task.  The broad research question is whether a preference for taste or healthiness attributes of food makes one more likely to avoid exposure to information that promotes the other attribute (healthiness or taste, respectively).  
Relatedly, this type of confirmation bias in information choice may lead one to discount the quality of arguments that promote the less preferred food attribute (e.g., a "taste" preference may lead one to consider more weak any argument that promote healthiness of food as opposed to promoting the importance of good tasting food).

q4.value:
Our first hypothesis is that a confirmation bias in food choice exists, and this confirmation bias will manifest both in information exposure choices, as well as in the perceived strength of arguments made surrounding the taste or healthiness of food.

Other hypotheses we have involve gender, BMI, and age. 
 We hypothesize that women (vs men), normal BMI (vs High BMI) and older adults (vs younger) will indicate a higher relative preference for healthiness over taste in food choice. 
 
With respect to a differential confirmation bias based on gender, BMI or age, we do not have any ex ante hypotheses and so analysis along those dimensions will be exploratory.

We will collect data on some favorability ratings of items related to dietary preference (e.g., "meat eaters, vegetarians, salty snacks, et) which will allow tests of hypotheses that those preferring health attributes of food more than taste will likely display higher favorability ratings for those items generally considered related to healthier living.

Finally, we hypothesize that more deliberation should reduce the size of the confirmation bias (we will proxy deliberation by examining self-reported sleepiness, thought put into the food choice issue (self-report), and outcomes on the cognitive reflection task).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: No.  All subjects will be administered the same survey.

question.value:
The task will be administered via survey on the Prolific platform, which will allow us to filter participants by Body Mass Index (BMI) and gender.  In this way, we can create 4 identical surveys (one for each design cell) and generate balanced samples of by BMI (High vs Normal) and gender (Male vs Female) using the survey delivery filtering.

The survey itself will contain basic demographic questions (verifying filters) as well as elicit preferences regarding food choice.  Importantly, we will elicit whether an individual considers tastiness or healthiness of food to be the more important attribute when making dietary choices.

The survey then asks about one's dietary health position and food knowledge, as well as elicit a few simple self-report sleep level questions (we have interest in the hypothesis that insufficient sleep also impacts food choice, which can be explored in this study but will be more formally tested in another project)

The next part of the survey will examine one's attitude strength and position extremity regarding food choice.  Then the participant will view a series of arguments that promote either the healthiness or the tastiness of food and indicate their level of agreement or disagreement with each statement.  This will be reassess after the "information board and argument strength" task that follows

The food "information board" task informs the participant that 10 information clips must be viewed.  For each information clip, the participant has the choice of whether to view a clip that promotes the tastiness of food or the healthiness of food.  The total number of "taste matters most" versus "healthiness matters most" clips viewed is a key outcome measure in assessing the confirmation bias.  We also capture time spent on each information clip page as a measure of response time that can be used to assess choice process.
After the information board task, the participant view a series of 6 arguments (3 pro-taste, and 3 pro-health) and must rate the strength of each argument as weak or strong.  Response times are also captured in the argument strength task.

Following the information board and argument strength task, we reassess (repeated measure) each participant's attitude strength and extremity of position regarding food choice, and the survey then ends with the administration of a 6-item cognitive reflection task as a way to identify participants who are more reflective or deliberative in their decision making (compared to those who are more automatic or intuitive).

q9.value: No randomization.  All subjects view the exact same decision tasks and differ only in the food information clips they will view based on their choices.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We will collect data using a Qualtrics-designed survey administered via the Prolific platform.  An identical survey will be administered to each of the following treatment groups: High BMI females, High BMI males, Low BMI females, Low BMI males.
We plan to administer a small 10 observation survey prior to the main data collection as a pilot sample to trouble shoot the survey platform and we will not analyze the pilot data results with the main data.

Pilot sample size will be n=10.
A sample size of n=100 for each design cell indicated above will be collected, for a total sample of n=400.

q14.value: Ex ante power analysis indicated a sample of n=395 is sufficient to identify small sized main effect on a single regression coefficient in a multivariate model with power = .80 (as recommended for the social sciences) at alpha=.05 level.

q15.value: Plan is to stop data collection when full n=100 sample is reached on each design cell.  Given the availability of individuals meeting our filter-criteria for the different experiment design cells, we do not anticipate any difficulty in obtaining the full n=100 respondents per cell (n=400 total)

question.value: What is manipulated is the type of subject that is administered the survey.  We will filter the subjects based on BMI and gender, specifically, so that we may control the data collection to get a balanced sample on each of our desired respondent types.

We will measure participant preferences on food choice, self-reported sleepiness levels, one's cognitive reflection score, attitude strength, extremity of position (regarding food choice). Key outcome measures will capture the number of information clips viewed of each type (pro-taste or pro-healthiness) as well as the perceived strength of arguments made promoting the importance of taste versus healthiness of food.  We also measure response times on the food information clip choices and the argument strength task by capturing time spent on the decision page.

Food information clips viewed will be combined into a single measure to identify total clips viewed in favor of one food attribute or the other.  Argument strength responses will be combined to created a singular metric of one's overall perception of argument strength in favor of one position or the other.  Extremity of position responses can also be combined into a singular measure representing one's position on taste versus healthiness of food.
Finally, cognitive reflection task responses are combined into a total number correct or a total number incorrect, but intuitively correct.
Hypotheses will be tested using nonparametric tests for unconditional analysis, as well as using multi-variate econometric estimations to condition the analysis on important co-variates.

q20.value: See previous description in "variables" area of this preregistration for a description of the recoding plan for the data from the Information Board and Argument Strength tasks.  In short, responses are combined into a single metric that will indicate strength of preference for one type of information or strength of attitude towards arguments favoring a particular viewpoint.

q21.value:
One-tailed tests will be used to test the confirmation bias hypotheses, as well as the hypothesis of a relatively higher preference for healthiness over taste in food attitudes among women, normal BMI, and younger participants.  

We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining whether the non-parametric tests suggest that the results are significant or not.

Note: we will also examine how deliberation affects the confirmation bias using both self-reported sleepiness as well as Cognitive Reflection Test (CRT) scores as a proxy for the amount of deliberation that goes into the choice task: sleepier or lower CRT score subjects are considered to use less deliberation in the confirmation bias tasks.  We also ask participants how much thought they have put into the specific issue of food choice.

q22.value:
An attention-check (poison pill) question is included within the survey.  Analysis will be conducted both with and without inclusion of those who fail the attention check.

Pilot data (n=10 participants) will not be analyzed for the study.  The purpose of the pilot data is to assess survey length and set compensation rate.

q23.value: If a subject does not complete at least three questions pertaining to health vs. tastiness in the survey that will not be included in the subsequent data analysis. (however, we will use survey settings that will presumably not allow a participant to leave questions blank on the survey)

q24.value:
One exploratory analysis to be run will examine whether there is any difference in the confirmation bias measures by gender, BMI group, or age. 

It will also be exploratory which cognitive measure best describes thought put into the task (i.e., self-reported sleepiness, CRT scores, or among of thought (self-reported) put into the issue of food choice.

Another exploratory analysis would be to look at whether strength of attitude and feelings regarding the issue of dietary choice impact the confirmation bias.

We will also conduct exploratory analysis with respect to response times (time spent on each information clip page)

Given the availability of individuals meeting our filter-criteria for the different experiment design cells, we do not anticipate any difficulty in obtaining the full n=100 respondents per cell (n=400 total)
registration_responses.q20: See previous description in "variables" area of this preregistration for a description of the recoding plan for the data from the Information Board and Argument Strength tasks.  In short, responses are combined into a single metric that will indicate strength of preference for one type of information or strength of attitude towards arguments favoring a particular viewpoint.
registration_responses.q21:
One-tailed tests will be used to test the confirmation bias hypotheses, as well as the hypothesis of a relatively higher preference for healthiness over taste in food attitudes among women, normal BMI, and younger participants.  

We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining whether the non-parametric tests suggest that the results are significant or not.

Note: we will also examine how deliberation affects the confirmation bias using both self-reported sleepiness as well as Cognitive Reflection Test (CRT) scores as a proxy for the amount of deliberation that goes into the choice task: sleepier or lower CRT score subjects are considered to use less deliberation in the confirmation bias tasks.  We also ask participants how much thought they have put into the specific issue of food choice.
registration_responses.q22:
An attention-check (poison pill) question is included within the survey.  Analysis will be conducted both with and without inclusion of those who fail the attention check.

Pilot data (n=10 participants) will not be analyzed for the study.  The purpose of the pilot data is to assess survey length and set compensation rate.
registration_responses.q23: If a subject does not complete at least three questions pertaining to health vs. tastiness in the survey that will not be included in the subsequent data analysis. (however, we will use survey settings that will presumably not allow a participant to leave questions blank on the survey)
registration_responses.q24:
One exploratory analysis to be run will examine whether there is any difference in the confirmation bias measures by gender, BMI group, or age. 

It will also be exploratory which cognitive measure best describes thought put into the task (i.e., self-reported sleepiness, CRT scores, or among of thought (self-reported) put into the issue of food choice.

Another exploratory analysis would be to look at whether strength of attitude and feelings regarding the issue of dietary choice impact the confirmation bias.

We will also conduct exploratory analysis with respect to response times (time spent on each information clip page)
registration_responses.q8.question:
The task will be administered via survey on the Prolific platform, which will allow us to filter participants by Body Mass Index (BMI) and gender.  In this way, we can create 4 identical surveys (one for each design cell) and generate balanced samples of by BMI (High vs Normal) and gender (Male vs Female) using the survey delivery filtering.

The survey itself will contain basic demographic questions (verifying filters) as well as elicit preferences regarding food choice.  Importantly, we will elicit whether an individual considers tastiness or healthiness of food to be the more important attribute when making dietary choices.

The survey then asks about one's dietary health position and food knowledge, as well as elicit a few simple self-report sleep level questions (we have interest in the hypothesis that insufficient sleep also impacts food choice, which can be explored in this study but will be more formally tested in another project)

The next part of the survey will examine one's attitude strength and position extremity regarding food choice.  Then the participant will view a series of arguments that promote either the healthiness or the tastiness of food and indicate their level of agreement or disagreement with each statement.  This will be reassess after the "information board and argument strength" task that follows

The food "information board" task informs the participant that 10 information clips must be viewed.  For each information clip, the participant has the choice of whether to view a clip that promotes the tastiness of food or the healthiness of food.  The total number of "taste matters most" versus "healthiness matters most" clips viewed is a key outcome measure in assessing the confirmation bias.  We also capture time spent on each information clip page as a measure of response time that can be used to assess choice process.
After the information board task, the participant view a series of 6 arguments (3 pro-taste, and 3 pro-health) and must rate the strength of each argument as weak or strong.  Response times are also captured in the argument strength task.

Following the information board and argument strength task, we reassess (repeated measure) each participant's attitude strength and extremity of position regarding food choice, and the survey then ends with the administration of a 6-item cognitive reflection task as a way to identify participants who are more reflective or deliberative in their decision making (compared to those who are more automatic or intuitive).
registration_responses.q12.question:
We will collect data using a Qualtrics-designed survey administered via the Prolific platform.  An identical survey will be administered to each of the following treatment groups: High BMI females, High BMI males, Low BMI females, Low BMI males.
We plan to administer a small 10 observation survey prior to the main data collection as a pilot sample to trouble shoot the survey platform and we will not analyze the pilot data results with the main data.
registration_responses.q16.question: What is manipulated is the type of subject that is administered the survey.  We will filter the subjects based on BMI and gender, specifically, so that we may control the data collection to get a balanced sample on each of our desired respondent types.
registration_responses.q17.question: We will measure participant preferences on food choice, self-reported sleepiness levels, one's cognitive reflection score, attitude strength, extremity of position (regarding food choice). Key outcome measures will capture the number of information clips viewed of each type (pro-taste or pro-healthiness) as well as the perceived strength of arguments made promoting the importance of taste versus healthiness of food.  We also measure response times on the food information clip choices and the argument strength task by capturing time spent on the decision page.
registration_responses.q18.question:
Food information clips viewed will be combined into a single measure to identify total clips viewed in favor of one food attribute or the other.  Argument strength responses will be combined to created a singular metric of one's overall perception of argument strength in favor of one position or the other.  Extremity of position responses can also be combined into a singular measure representing one's position on taste versus healthiness of food.
Finally, cognitive reflection task responses are combined into a total number correct or a total number incorrect, but intuitively correct.
registration_responses.q19.question: Hypotheses will be tested using nonparametric tests for unconditional analysis, as well as using multi-variate econometric estimations to condition the analysis on important co-variates.

question5a.value: The internet has revolutionized the way in which we consume news, and this migration from print to digital has fundamentally reshaped the economic structure of the media industry. Over a quarter of newspaper revenue now comes from digital advertising, with this share growing every year (Pew Research Centre, 2018). This puts pressure on newspapers to increase traffic to their websites in order to maximize revenues: this can be done through use of clickbait. Clickbait is a term used to describe articles and headlines written in a dramatic manner in order to grab users’ attention and get them to click onto and read additional content. The headline is made to seem exciting, but the content of the article may not always deliver on the promise of the headline. Clickbait uses our attention system to generate curiosity and cognitive arousal, causing us to engage more with content. Clickbait headlines results in negative effects on perceived source credibility (Hurst, 2016), and fake news stories with clickbait headlines were viewed 38 million times on Facebook prior to the 2016 US presidential election (Allcott & Gentzkow, 2017). The role of clickbait in the attention economy suggests that newspapers who have incentives to increase ad revenue will increase clickbait, and that clickbait will generally increase over time.
